title: Are Trump and Biden really the only two candidates we have to choose from? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, if you want your vote to matter. No, there are political parties other than the Democrats and the Republicans, and they will be running other candidates. But as a practical matter, those two parties are the only ones large enough to win elections on that level. It would be nice to have several viable parties to choose from, but those two parties are so large that it is a guarantee that one of them will win, and there is not enough time to change that before November. The idealist in me screams at this concept. I want other parties to get large enough to be competitive, but I can’t bring myself to do the one thing that would make that happen—voting for their candidates—because so few other people are that it would just be a wasted symbolic gesture rather than a good-faith attempt to influence the results of the election. My inner idealist points out that while I think even the Democrats are too far to the right, I live in a state that so consistently votes Republican that it is virtually guaranteed to back Trump, so I should just go ahead and vote for the person whom I most want to be president no matter which party they’re representing because it won’t matter anyway. But idealism always collapses in the face of reality. Barring some unforeseen circumstance removing one of them from the race, the fact is that next January, either Joe Biden is going to become the president, or Donald Trump is going to begin a second term. And I absolutely do not want Trump to get a second term. And since Joe Biden is, by virtue of being the Democratic candidate, the only person who could unseat him, it is Joe Biden I must vote for. I’m not an admirer of Biden. I wish the Democrats had chosen someone else. But they didn’t, and I have to accept reality as it is. To vote for a different party, or abstain from voting, because the Democrats didn’t give me the candidate I wanted would be making the perfect the enemy of the good. It’s extremely unlikely my state will go blue—1964 is the only time is ever has—but if we fall one vote short of doing that, and I voted for someone else because I assumed it wouldn’t make a difference? Screw that noise. One of the two is going to win. That’s a given. The only thing that isn’t a given is which one it will be, and voting for the Green Party candidate or the Libertarian Party candidate or anyone else is not going to change that. In a different election year, where the worst you could say about either candidate is that they’re uninspiring and aren’t likely to be a particularly good president, I might get behind the idea that more people need to vote for third parties so they can grow and eventually break the duopoly that the Democrats and Republicans hold on winning Federal elections. But this one is too important. If you like Trump, vote for him. If, like me, you despise him and want to see him out of office, vote for Biden. Even if you don’t like him, and you’re certain he’s going to be a bad president. First of all, a merely “bad” president would be an improvement. But secondly, if you want to get rid of Trump, then it is, unfortunately, not going to be helpful to simply vote for someone else, unless that someone is the one who could win, which means the Democratic candidate, which means Biden. We can worry about fixing the system once we’re back in a place of stability. We may or may not get to a place of stability under Biden, but we’ll at least be moving toward it, which is the opposite of what will happen if Trump stays. So no, it’s not literally true that you, individual voter, only have two choices. There will be plenty of names to choose from. But we, the country, collectively, will be choosing one of the two. So you can vote for Biden and try to help him win, or you can do literally anything else and thereby help Trump win. Vote Trump, vote a third party, stay home and watch Netflix, all amounts to helping Trump win, by virtue of denying a vote to the one person who can possibly unseat him. It’s Trump, or it’s Biden. Take your pick.

Are Trump and Biden really the only two candidates we have to choose from? Certainly not. There are two national third parties: the Green Party and the Libertarian Party, although whether either or both of those candidates will appear on the ballot depends on the state where you live. Howie Hawkins seems to be the likely candidate for the Greens, but the convention doesn’t start until July 9. The Green Party is currently on the ballot in something like 21 states and the party is petitioning for ballot access in the rest (except Washington and North Dakota where they are waiting for the proper date to roll around before they can start). Jo Jorgensen is the candidate for the Libertarians. The Libertarian Party has managed to appear on all 50 state ballots a few times in the past, but was only on 36 states’ ballots as of April. That has probably changed, but they haven’t updated their website to reflect it. There may also be write-in candidates who have met the requirements in your state, but you would need to check with your state’s election authority (usually the Secretary of State’s office) to find out. Now if your question is actually something along the lines of “are Trump and Biden the only two candidates who have a chance of winning the presidency?” then the answer is yes. At best, 3rd party presidential candidates act as spoilers by siphoning votes away from the two major-party candidates. Were it not for Ralph Nader (Green Party), Al Gore would have probably won Florida in 2000 and George W. would have gone home to Texas. Were it not for Ross Perot (Reform Party) in 1992, George HW would have probably been reelected and Clinton would have headed back to Arkansas. 3rd party presidential candidates do not have strong chances of winning on the national scale, but they can prevent one of the major candidates from winning one or more states under the right circumstances.

Yes and no. And I can explain what I mean by that. Right now, there are only two candidates that have a realistic chance of winning: Trump and Biden. You don’t have to vote for either. In some situations (and I did this when I was very young) you can vote for a third-party candidate. The goal of doing so is mainly to send a message, that neither of the candidates selected by either party are acceptable. And when a significant number of votes go to a third-party candidate, that might be the message that is received. That said, there is no third-party candidate that is likely to garner any significant number of votes, so voting for such a candidate serves no practical purpose. In other words, it would not be a rational use of your vote. I get that a lot of people do not like either candidate in the upcoming election (I’m not a fan of either, myself). BUT at least in my estimation, there really is a huge difference between Biden and Trump, and thus any vote to a third-party candidate would, in effect, be a vote for the person that will have the best chance of winning (because you would, effectively, not be voting, because your vote would not make any difference whatsoever — you may as well just stay home). So the question is, when deciding how you will vote, is do you perceive any significant difference in what would happen if one or the other candidate would win the election? If so, then if you want to make any kind of difference, vote for the candidate that you think would best for the future. Otherwise, you may as well not even vote. That’s basically it.

Yes, Trump and Biden are really the only two candidates we have to choose from. What does it mean that American voters have a choice between two old men, both of whom seem to be in the early stages of dementia? To me, it’s a slap in the face of the electorate—a tacit acknowledgement that the President of the United States is really only a figurehead, a placeholder for the military-industrial complex that actually runs the United States. In case you haven’t noticed, the USA is one of the very few developed countries with no single-payer healthcare, no guaranteed income, and no guaranteed housing, as well as a mediocre public school system, an expensive university system, and a ludicrously inadequate minimum wage. This is another hint that the country is actually run by people other than the three branches of government named in the Constitution: Executive, Congressional, and Judicial. Normal expectations of a government is that it will tax its citizens and build a physical and social infrastructure paid for by citizen taxes. For such a wealthy country, the USA has a remarkably lacking social infrastructure. The unacknowledged branch of the government also happens to have the highest budget: the military. Although technically it falls under the Executive branch (with the President as the Commander-in-Chief), the military appears to have as much or more power than the three acknowledged branches. There is very little difference in foreign policy between Republican and Democratic Presidential administrations; again, this is likely because the military-industrial complex is, in reality, an entity unto itself, no matter what the U.S. Constitution says. Why do I say the military-industrial complex rather than simply the military? Much of the military budget goes to incomprehensibly enormous and enormously wealthy private “defense” contractors such as Lockheed, Boeing, Raytheon, BAE, Northrop Grumman, General Dynamics, etc. Reference: List of defense contractors - Wikipedia It’s no coincidence that Trump’s recent “photo op” walking across Lafayette Square (which was forcibly cleared of peaceful Black Lives Matter protesters) to hold up a Bible at the closest church to the White House included the presence of General Mark Milley, the Chair of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Mark Esper, Defense Secretary, with Milley in battle fatigues and Esper having encouraged state governors to “dominate the battlespace” during a call earlier in the day. This may very well have been meant as an acknowledgement of the military’s power and influence on domestic policy. Reference: The battle of Lafayette Square and the undermining of American democracy Given the foreshadowing noted above, perhaps it should be no surprise that Trump has sent Federal thugs from indeterminable agencies, with no name tags nor badge numbers, and wearing rag-tag improvised military-style uniforms, to invade Portland, Oregon, and attack and arrest random protesters, despite the objections of mayors, governors, and much of Congress. And perhaps it should be no surprise that media outrage has been muffled, compared to the vocal outrage regarding the forcible clearing of Lafayette Square a month ago. With good reason, even notable and powerful people seem to be terrified. Oregon senator Ron Wyden warned the Senate Intelligence Committee today that the US presidential election could be held under martial law after federal police officers clashed with rioters during the 54th night of protests in his state's largest city. Mr. Wyden stated Portland has been "invaded by militarized law enforcement". Reference: 2020 presidential election may be held under 'martial law', warns senator Since the USA appears to be controlled by the wealthy and powerful few, our choice as voters is between two extremely inadequate men. Based on Trump’s inaction on the pandemic, his racist stance on the Black Lives Matter movement, and his executive order sending Federal thugs to invade U.S. cities despite the refusal of city mayors and state governors, I will very reluctantly vote for Biden, hoping he will be incrementally better than Trump. At this point, yes. In January, 2020, the answer to this question would have been something like “There are over 30 candidates currently running for office in two parties!” America (or … parts of America, at least ) have already looked at 32 Candidates and decided that they want one of the two remaining candidates to be president from 2021–2025.  But don’t worry, I’m sure Jill Stein or Ralph Nader will appear in September, after the votes of tens of millions of Americans have whittled the race down to two candidates. At that point, they’ll complain about how “rigged” America’s system is, and bemoan the lack of choice in the general election. and Just like in 2016, they’ll screw over whatever party they ideologically most resemble. And while I’d generally agree with them that we need ranked-choice voting, not having it means that this primary system is the best way we have to hear and meet the needs of the majority of the electorate.
